title: Physics-Informed Neural Network Surrogate Models for River Stage Prediction
authors: Maximilian Zoch, Edward Holmberg, Pujan Pokhrel, Ken Pathak, Steven Sloan, Kendall Niles, Jay Ratcliff, Maik Flanagin, Elias Ioup, Christian Guetl, Mahdi Abdelguerfi
abstract: This work investigates the feasibility of using Physics-Informed Neural Networks (PINNs) as surrogate models for river stage prediction, aiming to reduce computational cost while maintaining predictive accuracy. By integrating the governing Saint-Venant equations into the learning process, the proposed PINN-based surrogate model enforces physical consistency and significantly improves computational efficiency compared to HEC-RAS.

title: A surrogate approach to model groundwater level in time and space based on tree regressors
abstract: This research presents a machine learning approach to predict groundwater levels in time and space based on tree regressors. Algorithms tested include Random forest, ExtraTrees and gradient boosting regression, with generalization scores in excess of 0.95 for wet, dry and average climatic conditions.

title: Investigating Steady Unconfined Groundwater Flow using Physics Informed Neural Networks
abstract: A novel deep learning technique called Physics Informed Neural Networks (PINNs) is adapted to study steady groundwater flow in unconfined aquifers. This technique utilizes information from underlying physics represented in the form of partial differential equations (PDEs) alongside data obtained from physical observations.

title: Use of Multifidelity Training Data and Transfer Learning for Efficient Construction of Subsurface Flow Surrogate Models
abstract: This work presents a framework where most of the training simulations are performed on coarsened geomodels using flow-based upscaling. The framework entails the use of a transfer-learning procedure incorporated within an existing recurrent residual U-Net architecture. Using 2500 low-fidelity runs and 200 high-fidelity runs leads to about a 90% reduction in training simulation costs.

title: Efficient deep-learning-based surrogate model for reservoir production optimization using transfer learning and multi-fidelity data
authors: Jian-Wei Cui, Wen-Yao Sun, Hyojung Jeong, et al.
abstract: This study introduces a training procedure that leverages transfer learning with multi-fidelity training data to construct surrogate models efficiently. The method leads to about a 75% reduction in total computational cost compared to traditional training approaches without sacrificing prediction accuracy.

title: Deep operator network for surrogate modeling of poroelasticity with random permeability fields
abstract: The surrogate model is evaluated on two benchmark problems in poroelasticity: soil consolidation and ground subsidence induced by groundwater extraction. For each case, training datasets are generated from finite element simulations, achieving high predictive accuracy.

title: A Hybrid DSCNN-GRU Based Surrogate Model for Transient Groundwater Flow Prediction
abstract: This study develops a novel surrogate modelling approach, DSCNN-GRU, incorporating a deep separable convolutional neural network (DSCNN) and a gated recurrent unit (GRU), to efficiently capture temporal and spatial variations in groundwater head fields from transient groundwater flow models.

title: AI-enhanced groundwater management platform: A network-driven approach for simulation
abstract: Presents an AI-enhanced groundwater management framework (IGWM) that advances beyond traditional constraints by coupling physics-driven models (e.g., MODFLOW6) with surrogate learning approaches—Random Forest (RF) and Physics-Informed Neural Networks (PINNs)—to achieve both rapid simulation and physically consistent prediction.

title: Physics-informed surrogate modeling for supporting climate resilience at groundwater contamination sites
abstract: These models are capable of forecasting groundwater pollution levels under diverse climatic situations and subsurface characteristics without necessitating a supercomputer, supporting climate resilience at groundwater contamination sites.

title: Efficient Training of Deep-Learning-Based Surrogate Models for Subsurface Flow Simulation Using Multifidelity Data and Physics Constraints
abstract: Proposes a physics-constrained surrogate (PCS) model training approach for production optimization that integrates multifidelity training data together with physics constraints. The approach starts with model pretraining on low-cost, low-fidelity training data, followed by model fine-tuning with high-fidelity samples.

title: Multi-fidelity graph neural networks for efficient and accurate flood hazard mapping
abstract: Integrates multi-resolution data on unstructured meshes with hierarchical learning. Outperforms single-fidelity models in diverse fluvial and pluvial flood scenarios and reduces reliance on expensive high-fidelity data without sacrificing accuracy.

title: VAE-DNN: Energy-Efficient Trainable-by-Parts Surrogate Model For Parametric Partial Differential Equations
abstract: VAE-DNN is compared to the FNO and DeepONet models for obtaining forward and inverse solutions to the nonlinear diffusion equation governing groundwater flow in an unconfined aquifer, demonstrating greater efficiency and superior accuracy.

title: ConvLSTM-Based Surrogate Modeling for Flood Inflow Prediction at Namgang Dam
abstract: Examines the effectiveness of LSTM surrogate models in forecasting flood inflows, introducing a novel surrogate modeling approach that integrates physically simulated extreme scenarios generated by applying scale factors to observed rainfall data within the HEC-HMS model.

title: A surrogate machine learning model using random forests for real-time flood inundation simulations
abstract: Addresses limitations by integrating hydrological parameters such as upstream discharge and physical catchment characteristics to enhance predictive accuracy and generalizability in flood inundation simulations.

title: Improved physics-informed neural network for reactive transport modeling of groundwater arsenic enrichment
abstract: The PH-PINNs model significantly outperforms traditional PINNs in capturing nonlinear and non-stationary dynamics, reducing the root mean square error (RMSE) by over 50% for groundwater arsenic transport modeling.

title: Incorporating Deep Learning Into Hydrogeological Modeling: Advancements, Challenges, and Future Directions
journal: Journal of Geophysical Research: Machine Learning and Computation
abstract: Reviews the integration of deep learning approaches as efficient surrogate models for uncertainty quantification in hydrogeological modeling, handling non-Gaussian parameter fields and complex uncertainty scenarios.
